Academics.Review: Amazing Classes – Classes are very interesting and intriguing. Professors have open office hours every week to meet with you one on one. Professors are some of the leading figures in their fields, so to be able to pick their brains is a great experience.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: Ecology & Evolutionary Biology – It has a low faculty:student ratio and really committed professors. They are the best or up-and-coming in their fields and love to have undergrads in their labs. It is easy to get funding for summer research on campus and you can do research for pay or credit or just as a volunteer. With all the new labs opening all over campus, there are tons of research & job opportunities.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: Best Freshmen Experience – I had always been my dream to go to yale and I finally was able to put my dreams into action and I began my freshmen year here Fall 2009. Great atmosphere, community, and the teachers really seem to care about the students. It was just everything I imagined it would be :) I did ultimately leave to attend school closer to home but I would do it all over again if I could.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: Comparative Literature – Very flexible and open to cater to your own interests. The added foreign lit requirement is a plus from the English major, and forces you to really take a second language farther. The faculty have been amazing and are very accessible.
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review: It Doesn't Get Better Than This – Famous professors teaching undergraduates...and teaching them well.  Seminars in which you, nine fellow students, and a professor have interesting discussions and heated debates.  Lots of support and help if you need them.  Academics at Yale are as good as advertised.  Yale has changed the way I think in a meaningful and positive way.  Many of Yale's professors are serious, committed, and talented *teachers*, which is rarer than you'd think on elite research campuses.  Great teachers at Yale include Steven Smith (Political Philosophy), Norma Thompson (Humanities), Michael Frame (Mathematics), Mark Johnson (Chemistry), and Edwin Duval (French Literature).  Moreover, when you do have TAs, they're typically quite good.  My Constitutional Law TA, for instance, was a former top-ranked college debater who encouraged us to make arguments about the constitution and challenged us on our ideas.  Oh, and she also baked us brownies.  I should also mention the Directed Studies program for freshman.  It's a year-long, three seminar introduction to Western Civilization, and it's a chance to get great teaching and individual attention from senior faculty starting the first class day of your freshman year.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: best professors, best history and chinese departments in the world (i'm sure there's more), TAs can sometimes be ~~ but you'd expect that at any school.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: You will learn to think.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: History Dept. is the Best – Yale has the best history department in the world. The library collections are enormous and quirky (this year I got to handle bomb fragments from the Haymarket Riot), and history majors are basically empowered to start producing top-notch scholarship even as undergrads.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: None Better – Yale really pours resources into its academics, and it shows.  Professors are very available and often offer to go to coffee, have lunch, or hold office hours with students.  Seminars are widely available - in three semesters, I have had mostly small seminars with awesome professors, and that was even without having declared a major.  The workload at Yale is intense, and though it is not hard to get acceptable grades, doing well requires a lot of work.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: New Haven is beautiful... As long as you're on campus. When you're off, there are some interesting people, to word it nicely. There are many interesting shops and places to eat, however, most of them are very expensive.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: New Haven has plenty of cool things to do. However, it's very easy to get bored of things after a while. It takes some exploring sometimes but there are definitely more than enough things to do here. Plus, train access to NYC is really easy and pretty cheap, so if you run out of things to do here, you can hop over to NYC for more.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: New Haven is a much safer and friendlier city than you might have heard. Students don't venture too far away from campus, and the areas they do go are local destinations for a reason. Plus, it's very easy to catch a train to New York City.
Campus.Author: Recent Alumnus

Campus.Review: Some parts are nice while other parts are not as nice and can even be dangerous.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Very big area with different atmospheres in nearby towns.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Not the safest area but the town is diverse and alive.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: I didn't leave campus much, but some students got really involved in local politics. New York was pretty easily accessible
Campus.Author: Recent Alumnus

Campus.Review: new haven is kind of a fake town. a lot of the off campus retail is owned by yale and mostly they put in very expensive clothing stores and lifestyle shops (e.g. j press, origins, more than one art selling shop). outside of yale it's not very vibrant. it's also a food desert: there are literally no grocery stores within ~0.5 miles of yale except elm city market, which is a struggling co-op (shelves often bare). you can take a bus to stop and shop if you want.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: I feel safer than I was led to believe being in New Haven. Major shopping cannot be done without taking a drive out to West Haven for malls and strip malls, which is difficult because having a car on campus is pretty difficult. There are zip cars but not everyone can access them depending on their driving history. The city is not terribly exciting, but if you look hard enough, integration could be a nice experience.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Housing is okay. I thought it was good at first but after staying the night with a friend at harvard for the Game I have to say I feel kind of let down. Facilities are fine but not as nice as they could be. Dining is excellent, labs are okay.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: there's a lot of great restaurants and pizza places
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Yale has an absolutely beautiful campus.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: The libraries are fantastic and full of anything you would want to study. The town as a whole is fantastic-though in the central green there is a major homeless problem.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: The concert halls, libraries, athletic facilities, and outdoor campus are stunningly beautiful and effective. The opportunities in the community to create off-campus events are also very excellent.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: New Haven has everything you really need to have a good time. But it's not New York....you'll eventually find yourself going to the same places every time. NYC and Boston are close by though, so it's easy to get out of New Haven.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: I've never had trouble finding an open computer in the labs or the libraries. You could get away with not having a laptop, but I think it'd be very annoying to be stuck in the labs/libraries to do all your work since everything requires working online or on a computer. No complaints about the internet, and the ITS people are very helpful. Cost of printing can add up quick though.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: I've definitely found my car to be useful, especially for grocery store trips. Parking on the street can add up, and they hand out tickets pretty diligently.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Free shuttle takes you almost everywhere you need to go. It doesn't always keep to schedule though, and on weekends they cut down on the number of buses quite a bit.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Snow can be pretty bad, and Yale doesn't believe weather should get in the way of learning.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Gets me where I need to go. Fast, and free.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: It is good and easy to access.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: It gets really cold in the winter and besides sledding and snowball fights there's not much students can do. The rest of the year the weather is fairly nice.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: We even got free iPads for one of my classes.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Hard to find parking near campus.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Cold, rainy, humid and mehhh....
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: The weather is pretty awful and there isn't much to do in New Haven, but Yale campus is really all you need!
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: The quality of the labs depends on which labs you are using. The internet is pretty slow--probably a bandwidth thing because it especially sucks for streaming. Printing is really easy. It's not free, but it's very cheap.
Campus.Author: Recent Alumnus

Campus.Review: There are sunny days and cloudy days and rainy days and snowy days, just like any other location. I give it a high rating because there are so many ways to take advantage of the sunny days. A walk down Broadway or Chapel, a stroll across the New Haven Green, a hike up East Rock, or simply lying lazily (or studiously) on Old Campus, Cross Campus, or in any of the courtyards. Lots of the colleges have swings or hammocks and patio furniture. The seasons are mostly beautiful--blowing leaves in the fall, first snow in the winter, flowering bulbs and tress in the spring, and shady trees in the summer. There are downsides, like when the snow gets dirty, but building igloos or jumping in leaf piles makes up for it. So I guess what I mean to say is that no matter what the bad days are like, you remember the good times you had in good weather long after you graduate, and the bad weather you mostly forget.
Campus.Author: Recent Alumnus

Campus.Review: I never had a car on campus myself, but I heard so many horror stories of break-ins that I don't think I ever would bring a car to New Haven.
Campus.Author: Recent Alumnus

Campus.Review: It is much earier to have your own computer, preferably a laptop, because you can do your work whenever you want and not have to worry about finding a computer.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: I haven't met anyone without a laptop here, but the university has so many incredible resources to supplement that, including Bass Library's Media Reserve and IT help.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: New Haven is actually a great city, despite its bad rep for safety. There is so much to do and see, whether you're into the outdoors, the arts, food, etc.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: New England weather! We have all the seasons, which means snow, rain, sunshine, etc. But the nice thing is that CT never gets anything too extreme. (Exceptions were Hurricane Sandy and Winter Storm Nemo, but hey...)
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: It's cold and gray often
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Best professors in the nation
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Always something eventful going on
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Everything is super convenient though printing could be cheaper!
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: The shuttles are convenient and useful to get to class on time.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: The technology and network is top notch
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Perks of being in an old wealthy college
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: the facilities are generally in great shape.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Its a well medium sized city centered around the college which is perfect not too big not too small
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: There are a lot of different clubs and activities for you to do. People are all really active.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: The classes are tough but you learn a lot and the people are really nice.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Lots of Dell computers that do not work very well - sometimes they run out of disk space too
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: The people are generally very kind towards the students and there very rarely any problems
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: The computer labs are stocked with the latest computer software and technology. Labs are easily accessed and computers are always available.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Much is invested in the welfare of facilities and all students are able to access the facilities
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: The facilities are well-maintained and afford many perks
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: The snow is beautiful and the cold is not as troublesome as one would expect
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: The atmosphere is okay, like I honestly don't have much to say on the subject because if you want to you can actually just ignore the city population or the population of nearby universities, but on the other hand if you want you can totally interact a lot with other universities. It's just your personal preference.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Okay, I'm from the South, like extremely southern, like coastal southern, and that probably makes me biased. However, it's freezing in the winter. I mean FREEZING. I've never felt cold like this in my entire life. I mean, finally seeing snow for the first time was awesome, but then it NEVER WENT AWAY. It's not enough to make me regret the decision to attend this school, but let's just say I don't leave the dorm much when it's winter.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: When the shuttle is running on time, it's pretty convenient, but it often does not function well and having to wait outside in the cold is terrible
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: It's New Haven - enough said
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Social scene is good, but the graduate schools don't have great campus space
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Science and technology facilities are mediocre, but the school has wonderful speaker series
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: No one drives at Yale; there's no reason to drive anywhere.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Yale has blazingly fast Wi-Fi compared to other top schools.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: As long as you have common sense, you'll be fine in New Haven.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: The shuttles are everywhere, so it's easy to find one.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: The students here are always very happy with Yale.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: The facilities are fantastic, and they are all generally close together.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: It's occasionally rainy, and it can get very cold, but it is great weather for New England.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Everyone on campus has their own laptop. That being said, there are a million computer labs and printing is relatively cheap. Network reliability: the network probably goes down for 5 minutes twice a month and for those five minutes, it is literally the worst because you NEED your internet right NOW. Network speed = lightning speed. Never seen a faster connection.
Campus.Author: College Student

Campus.Review: Everything and everywhere is gorgeous. So many ridiculously beautiful study spots. Student hangouts = mostly in dorms or in dining halls or wherever they find a place to sit, which could literally be anywhere.
Campus.Author: College Student

Campus.Review: New Haven is a wonderfully cultural city, it reminds me of 'little New York'. Shopping, restaurants, museums are all downtown and take kindly to the student population.
Campus.Author: College Student

Campus.Review: Parking is ample for permit holders and all university parking lots open to the public after a certain hour in the afternoon.
Campus.Author: College Student

Campus.Review: The shuttle at Yale is free although service can sometimes be somewhat spotty. The campus is pretty compact, however, so it's not impractical to simply walk everywhere.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: This is probably the worst thing about Yale. The best times to be on campus are the first 2 months of the school year and the last month. In between lies many cold, often snowy days.This mainly poses a problem when walking to and from classes. There's also a lot of humidity.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: There are phenomenal amounts of opportunities given by the school! The best part, in my opinion, is the residential college system. When you matriculate to the university, you are randomly placed into one of 12 residential colleges, and you typically remain in that college until graduation. You live within your college for every year past freshman year, and each college has its own dining hall, gym, kitchen, laundry room, restaurant, intramural teams, and more! This system fosters a camaraderie and creates friendships and bonds that I do not think are possible otherwise.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: There are lots of cultural activities available in New Haven, but students tend to be afraid of the city. As a result, most of the social life takes place on campus, but people also go to NYC for museums, etc. New Haven has great restaurants, though--Ethiopian, Malaysian, pizza...
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Campus life is student life at Yale. Secret societies and a cappella are very big deals...People are just as competitive about extracurriculars as they are about academics, if not more. Prime examples include the Yale Political Union (2 all-night commitments per week) and the Yale Daily News (an even more rigorous commitment).
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Very good computers; small clusters located in every(?) residential college. Bigger clusters tend to be further away (Hillhouse and Prospect), though they're sparsely used. Every student has his own laptop, and that's probably true across nearly all colleges by now.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Yale has a wonderful shuttle system that runs every day of the week. Also, there are emergency shuttles that can be called any time of the day.  The routes are very convenient and link all of campus.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Computers are all accessible and close and helpful. There are available computers in every library and computer labs in all twelve colleges, so if you have to print something, you sign up for an account (each page is 10 cents at most) and you don't have to walk far. If you finish something in your room, you can just email it to yourself and print it from a computer downstairs in the lab, which is in the basement of the college you live in, so not far at all. And if you're in one of the big libraries, there are computers there as well. Network reliability is good and fast. Wifi is good. There isn't a single person without a laptop (though technically you could just use the computers available), but you totally don't need a printer.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: It's a nice-looking campus. Yale is famous for its architecture. There are twelve college libraries and some other bigger, more famous libraries. It takes a while to figure out what the best study location for you is, but once you do, it's amazing.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: It's cold at Yale, but there's only a five minute walk to classes for me, and I don't notice it. Indoor heating is great, and it's fun to wear winter clothes. So for me, at least, the cold East coast weather isn't a problem.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: The only time I've really used Yale transportation was taking the shuttle up Science Hill. As long as you're on time, the shuttle will be there. In going off campus, a friend of mine uses ZipCar, but the essentials (toilet paper, toothbrushes, laundry detergent) are definitely within walking distance.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: New Haven is all right as far as college towns go. There's been some historical tension between Yalies and New Haven residents, but things have gotten better over the years, and I've even seen "Go Bulldogs! Beat Harvard!" signs in store windows around Thanksgiving for the Game. There are only a couple of stores within walking distance that are worth visiting, but if you want pizza and ice cream/froyo, you've come to the right place.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Computing is generally fine, pretty much everyone is on the wifi all the time, which is very easy to get on.  The student tech collaborative does repairs for free and is very competent.  Computer labs are usually amply supplied, and printing works well enough. Oh, and we get 50 free GB of cloud storage.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: New Haven is a lovely small city.  It has plenty to do in terms of local events, dining, museums, and other culture.  There are a few problems.  First, town-gown relations remain kind of strained, and that reduces the friendliness of some locals, the ease in arranging student discounts, and the like.  Second, New Haven still suffers from the perception of danger, and some neighborhoods do have a lot of crime.  While students are very safe on campus, this creates a bit of a psychological barrier to really exploring and enjoying what is a beautiful town.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: The weather is acceptable.  What does this mean?  We put up with it.  Winters could use more snow - there's a bit too much desolate gray-ness as it stands now.  August and September should be less humid, and then it also needs to rain less in March and April.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Yale's transportation is quite good.  While it can sometimes be a pain in the butt to get to New Haven from the West Coast, the school itself is in the middle of downtown, and the campus is very dense and walkable.  Buses run throughout, and also offer services to the Medical School and Union Station.  There are, however, a few problems.  Bus frequency is probably too low, especially to Union Station and up Science Hill.  Buses should run no more than ten minutes apart on these routes, preferably less.  While Yale is quite well situated relative to the station for the Metro-North, there is a problem, especially on evenings and weekends, with how the bus service oftentimes is slow to meet arriving trains, and buses frequently have insufficient space to accommodate the many people arriving on campus at once from any given train.  Finally, while this is not a transportation issue per se, there are a number of dangerous intersections and crossings, especially at Elm and York, and Grove and College/Prospect.  Something must be done about these.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Campus is beautiful. Facilities are constantly being renovated and updated, so even though you'll see a lot of classical or antique-looking architecture, everything inside, whether it be the workout machines at Payne Whitney Gymnasium or the computers in Sterling Memorial Library, are up to date.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Weather in New Haven can be pretty dreary sometimes. We're really close to the ocean so it rains a lot. Weather is really bipolar. It snows an average amount but once the weather turns nice, everyone comes to hang out outside.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: The campus looks like Hogwarts.  The facilities are great with up to date technology.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Great facilities and all the resources you could want.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: There's a myriad of organizations and interest groups, and there's always something going on. I'm in love with the Gothic architecture. Residential college system makes everything convenient, with localized reading rooms, underground tunnels, gyms, snack bars etc.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Yale provides exceptional access to resources, from its massive library, brilliant professors, to grants for summer research and internships. Most courses are academically rigorous, while overall curriculum has a flexible liberal arts approach.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Computers are always available for those who need them, but most people use their own laptops. Yale's WiFi is mostly reliable, but occasionally spotty. There's always tech help if you need it.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Yale has top notched information technology services including the ability to print from anywhere on campus.  We are a bit jealous of the Forestry School who has unlimited printing.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: They are pretty liberal with parking here and few tickets or tows are actually done.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Public transportation is free and the Yale shuttle service is constantly running. There are also additional services such as zip cars and taxis that can take students to the train station. New Haven has its own train station and airport, both of which are very accessible. Just a 2 hour train ride away is New York City, so flying out of New York is not an inconvenience at all.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: It is a beautiful campus with very nice facilities.  Yale's architecture is very impressive when you first see it-- it grows on you as you spend more time here.  There is no student center but the residential colleges (all of which are beautiful) serve the same purpose.  During all the seasons except winter, people spend time outside in courtyards or on Old Campus and it's very nice.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: All of it is metered, and actual parking lots are few and far between. That said, if you are looking for one on the average day, you can find a place easily enough. Most students on campus don't have cars, and rent zip cars if/when they need one.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: Parking at night can be quite simple, but during the day, it's horrible. Our campus is right next to downtown New Haven, and it's a bit complicated.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: Yale offers the best transportation options of any university I've ever been to.  24 hours around the clock!
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Yale does a good job with weather related issues.  Doesn't affect me much
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Having not lived in a city that has four distinct seasons before, it has been a little rough getting used to having to layer up in the winter. As long as you bring a heavy coat and snow boots, you should be fine. And make sure to check the weather before you go outside. Just because the sun is out doesn't mean it's above freezing.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Yale is unique in having all the resources of a big research university, while still providing an amazingly close-knit community. The residential college system definitely helps provide this sense of togetherness, by breaking up the students into smaller groups that they can identify with and grow really close to. I honestly cannot emphasize how great this system is. Coming from a very small high school, I was nervous about acclimating to a large school in a city. Yale's welcoming environment, and the amazing people I met in my residential college in the first few days, made the transition seamless for me. The people at Yale are so interesting and friendly that it is practically impossible to not make friends.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Yale's facilities are absolutely phenomenal. For starters, the campus is gorgeous. There are a lot of green spaces considering Yale is in a city; there is the requisite idyllic freshman quad with students playing frisbee when it's warm out. Most of the architecture is done in the Gothic style, and the main library, Sterling, was literally modeled in the image of a cathedral. In fact, there are numerous libraries you can choose from to study in, so you never get bored of being in the same place. With the residential college system, you have basically every kind of amenity you could wish for. Each college has its own dining hall and gym, and many have dance studios, theaters, music practice rooms, etc. Most residential colleges have a place called "the buttery," a little cafe where students can get things like milkshakes and mozzarella sticks late at night. The interiors of the colleges (and many buildings) have been recently renovated, so even though the campus looks old-fashioned, everything is up-to-date and in top condition on the inside. As for athletic facilities, we, ironically, have the biggest gymnasium in the world.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Yale offers a shuttle service that is reliable with an app that tells you how close it is (TransLoc). They also have a pick-up service but I've never been able to use it because it's always backed up/has too many people calling.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: At Yale, there is really no need to have a car. Everything is within a two-mile radius and campus shuttle services are reliable. The only place that's a bit farther (like a 10-15 minute walk) is the infamous "Science Hill", which, depending on your classes you may never even need to take the hike up there.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: The social scene is vibrant--everyone is way too involved in extracurricular life. Whatever you end up deciding to study, there are plentiful resources for it. The proximity to NYC is nice. It can feel as small or as large as you want it to, but it's more fun if you try on a few different activities and academic hats.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: The bus system at yale is very good and there are taxis available everywhere at any time.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Solid amounts of precipitation bit you get all four seasons.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: The social and campus life are all awesome. Something is always going on.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Although Yale is in one of the biggest cities in New Haven, there isnt much to do besides the local restaurant scene. There is a movie theater if you are interested in that. Also Toads hosts Dance parties for Yale University and Quinnipiac University students twice a week and there are usually regular concerts for big name and small name artists alike. But in general, New Haven can be dangerous if you are walking by yourself in a sketchy area at night. But if you are smart, you will most likely be safe. There is campus police, blue phones located all around campus, and Minibuses and security cars that you can call so you dont walk by yourself in a sketchy area. But mainly, most of the attractions are on campus. There is the science peabody museum, the british art gallery, the world renown yale art gallery which will open after 4 years of renovation in December, theaters, etc... If you are into a fine arts, there are regular happenings on campus. Also residential colleges tend to fund and host field trips. Although New Haven isnt necessarily provide the greatest local atmosphere, Yale does a very good job to compensate for this.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: Since people don't often go into New Haven, Yale has a booming on campus student life. Both the residential colleges and Yale itself provides a ridiculous amount of funding into student activities to the point that you will almost never be bored. Each residential college has a gym, but there is also a general atheltic center (Payne Whitney Gymnasium) with tons of awesome facilities which are open to varsity athletes and non athlethes alike. There are tons of libraries and pretty much a lot of interesting places to study if you don't want to study in your room. There are lots of campus events scheduled throughout the year and fun traditions to look forward to like SPRING FLING and Harvard Yale football game. Like I said there are a myridad of campus activities and a bunch of student hangouts.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: We have the residential college system which is analagous to the houses in Hogwartz in the Harry Potter movie/books. Before you even move in, you are automatically affiliated with a residential college which stays with you all 4 years. Its great because you already feel like you are part of something at the beginning. Although not required of you, your class mates in your residential college can be some of your best friends by the time you graduate. Each residential college has its own quirks and pretty much everybody has strong residential pride along with the general Yale pride by the time they graduate.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: Yale's life on campus is great- we have many study breaks, grassy lawns everywhere to hangout, dozens of party options each weekend, and more.  All of our facilities are very up to date, even though buildings are over 100 years old.  Pretty much every weekend there is an event such as Spring Fling, International barbecue, and more.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: What makes Yale different is the residential college system.  Other schools try to replicate it but usually can't form residential colleges as well as Yale can.  Here we have 12 different residential colleges, which freshman are randomly put into before they arrive on campus.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Printing Is Pretty Rough – Printers at Yale require payment per sheet, and are not particularly reliable.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Winter Woes – The weather here is never that bad, but when the winter comes, it kind of gets dreary. People are always inside and rarely go out at night. Also, when it snows, classes are RARELY cancelled. However, getting through the winter makes the spring so much better.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Everything is metered, and the cops around there are pretty harsh about handing out tickets.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: Everything Is Reachable! Campus shuttles take you everywhere you need to go, taxis are always abundant, local buses run regularly.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: ...some are old, some don't connect well to the printers.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: Rainy and Cold – Weather here sucks. It rains a lot, and it's super cold in the winter. But it's Yale, so who cares?
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Really Cold – New Haven is in New England, and you are here from September until early May. That means you get hit with chilly Autumn and frigid Winter, with temperatures that stay pretty steadily cold and weather that alternates between rainy and clear. Normal, sunny days are a godsend. The Gothic architecture is nice, though.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Accomodating and Inexpensive – Yale's public transportation provides all students with travel options for on and off-campus. On campus, the public transportation is most commonly used, but there are also buses that travel between our larger venues. Off campus, Yale provides zip-cars which allow students to travel off campus. These zip-cars  are charged at a fair rate, and some organizations within Yale provide a discounted rate.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Fun City – Fun city-lots to do and just a train ride away from NYC!
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: A free Yale shuttle bus will take you to the train station and around the Campus.
Campus.Author: Recent Alumnus

Campus.Review:
Very Good – Gyms is awesome
Labs are awesome
Libraries are very nice
Campus.Author: Recent Alumnus

Campus.Review: It rains; it snows; it's sunny; it's cloudy. So there's some of everything.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: New Haven is not terrible, but not nice. New Haven often gets a bad rap but stereotypes often are built on truth. New Haven is not a nice city and not the type of place you can go wandering around at night, especially as a woman. That said, there are a few good shops on Chapel and Elm because the area immediately surrounding Yale has been heavily gentrified.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: Busy Body – Everyone is so busy with their own activities, let it be clubs, varsity sports, archipelago, orchestra, the Yale Daily News, part-time jobs and studying. Yet even though everyone is juggling with ten things at once, everyone manages to have time to still meet up with friends and hang out either in the dining halls or at parties. The community is definitely tight and friendly.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Quite gorgeous if you enjoy an acute sense of seasonal change. Fantastic colorful falls, somewhat oppressive winters, with gorgeous and rejuvenating springs to make up for it. Not as cloudy as some people think.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: General Aesthetics – The combination of gothic architecture and efficient use of green space (trees, grass, etc) makes Yale both inherently aesthetically pleasing as well as welcoming and 'natural.'
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Most Yale students don't interact with New Haven residents much on a regular basis.  Some interactions come through service organizations, but a lot of Yale students keep to the Yale bubble.  While it doesn't have the greatest reputation, the area of New Haven immediately surrounding Yale feels safe and is kept up well.  The food is amazing (great pizza and Thai), but the shops can leave something to be desired.  While we live in New Haven, you shouldn't ignore the accessibility of New York.  Many students, especially upperclassmen, take day trips there on the weekends.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: New Haven is a city. Cars are problematic on campus as there is no parking. Yale has a good bus system, but most kids walk where they need to go and it's totally doable. The trains are a great way to head to NY or DC.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: A car is most definitely not needed at all. Everything is in walking distance and public transportation is great. If you do bring a car (or if parents are coming), watch out because the police do like to enforce parking rules and give out tickets.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: So Much Variety! Every facility you can imagine is available to you. There is a huge gym that provides exercise programs and classes for a fee (or you can just go with your friends and use the equipment). Every residential college also has a gym. There are numerous libraries on campus with a daunting number of books, and they are very nice places to study. The campus is absolutely beautiful and every student has access to amazing resources.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Always Something to Do – Plenty of great restaurants, clubs, and bars, especially for such a mid-sized city the quality of food in the area is great.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Get a Laptop, but Pretty Good Anyways! EVERYONE has a laptop, making the (many) computer clusters quite underutilized.  WiFi coverage is excellent, no complaints!!  I have my own printer, and its a lot more convenient than trying to use the campus ones, though some people make it work.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: New Haven's atmosphere isn't too great, especially compared with Yale's. The events that Yale offers are almost always more interesting than events in the surrounding area. The local attitude toward students is mixed.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: New Haven isn't exactly a cultural hotspot, although there are things to do. More often, however, you'll find that Yale events are much more interesting. Local attitude toward students is mixed.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Computer labs that are nearest to the dorms can be some of the rowdiest locations. Printing can be a nightmare, and sometimes it seems that the computers provided by the school are rigged against your success. I've had a computer stop reacting to me 15 minutes before a deadline for an essay.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: You're surrounded by students and professors who are ridiculously brilliant and talented, and yet never fail to be friendly. Things can get super stressful, but what do you expect with some of the best academics around? And as a bonus, there's a gorgeous campus with surprisingly good cafeteria food.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Pretty Easy to Get Around – It's pretty easy to get around-- everything is within walking distance, there are shuttles and minibuses if you get lost, are injured, feel threatened, or are just lazy (this last one is why most people use the shuttles up science hill, I think.)  Public buses are pretty cheap as well.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Don't Bring a Car! It's very costly and unnecessary since there is so much public transportation (campus shuttles, buses, trains, etc). And there is not a lot of parking available!!!
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Its Cool – If you're 21 and like drinking. Many community activities. Exploing is a must theres a lot to see.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: The libraries here are fantastic - we have 24, and if you can't find a book chances are they can get it for you or it's in the e-library.  Makes research super easy.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Free (fast) wifi virtually everywhere, and printers and computers within less than a block of all the dorms.  The wifi has only been down once within my coming here, and it was only for about an hour.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Walk around Sterling Memorial, Bass or Beinecke Libraries, and you'll know what I mean. Absolutely first-class.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Well Connected – MetroNorth line for New York, barely used local airport, excellent campus shuttle. Really not an issue.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Accessible and Reliable – Very good. PCs and Macs readily available. Printing costs a little on the high side. Bring a laptop, though, or you won't survive here.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: An Uninteresting City – Yale is New Haven's biggest asset, and it would be nice if the town recognised that a little more. The best thing that can be said for New Haven is that it's on the Metro North line to NYC. It's also difficult to run out of things to do on the Yale campus.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Parking on campus is available pretty much anywhere. As long as you have quarters handy, you can always find a spot for a few hours. If you want to park year round, it's easy to get a permit, and the garages are safe and not too far away.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: It's a Handful – There's quite a bit to see and do, from the local restaurants to just places to hang out on the weekend.  There are frequently events hosted by New Haven which provide a bunch of entertainment.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Yale=awesome. Everything is wonderful and they are really committed to their students
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Bus System – The bus system is very good. There are buses that take you anywhere on campus and there is a live feed that keeps you informed of where the buses are at what times.  Sometimes the bus times are not consistent though.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: No Need for Cars – There is really no need for cars on campus. Everything is within walking distance (shopping, groceries, school supplies, etc.) and if you really need to go far from campus, you can rent a zipcar or take a bus for $1.25.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Very Easy to Use – Yale is an urban campus. Transportation is almost negligible.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: The facilities are mostly really great. There are gyms in every residential college as well as the main one in a cathedral-like building, at least twenty libraries, many different dining halls (although they serve the same food) and so many resources at our disposal. The campus is beautiful, and there are so many performance spaces, practice spaces, art studios, etc. We don't have any kind of central student location, however, which isn't a huge deal, but would be nice. Another thing that would improve this category would be better proximity to the athletic fields from central campus.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: I see a great organized parking place, but as of now I do not drive.
Campus.Author: College Student

Campus.Review: Always There – Everyone has their own laptops, but the computer labs and libraries are always available for extra research.
Campus.Author: College Student

Campus.Review: Not Exactly the Nicest Place in the World – There's not much going on in New Haven. It's not a very safe place, and everything important or interesting is in some way connected to Yale.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: There are enough bus lines and they run frequently enough so traveling is convenient.  The mini bus is always slow on the weekends, because drunk people always use it unnecessarily to get food.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: I Dont Have a Car – I dont have a car. I dont need a car. If someone I know has a car, they easily find parking for it.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: we have wirless, there are more than enough computers. I didnt have a working laptop for about an entire semester, it was not a problem
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: New Haven does not seem to have that much going on of interest to Yale students beyond Yale-related events.  There are tons of these, to be sure.  It would be possible to go to at least two or three concerts every week if one had the time.  The Peabody museum is worth a perusal.  The area right around campus has quite a few restaurants.  The Schubert theater puts up some good shows.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: You Don't Really Need a Car Anyway – There is parking available, but there really isn't much reason for a car.  Campus is pretty compact and walkable.  The parking that does exist is pretty expensive.  However, you can get a zip car to drive, which is like a rental that you can pick up whenever you need it.  They are reasonably priced.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: It's a wash – There is good transportation for nearby travel. We have a minibus and various school buses that will take you anywhere you want to go in a nearby radius. Public transportation is not that great in New Haven from what I've seen, so if you want to go anywhere farther, make friends with someone who has a car.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: Good labs, and reasonably good printing service. The few times my computer has broken down, I always had a good alternative.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: We're in New Haven – Nearest airports are JFK, Hartford, and possibly New Haven (but this last one is pretty small).
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: Metro-North Is the Best – Metro-North is an excellent example of how government programs can improve both transportation and cultural values. I'm serious. The Metro-North line to New York is the best public transportation I've ever encountered, not just because it works and because it's insanely cheap, but because everybody is friendly and enjoys it. It encourages public transportation to be socially valued, which matters a lot in this day and age.
Campus.Author: Recent Alumnus

Campus.Review:
We're smart. Each of us is a little bit of a geek. But we're diverse geeks. There are history geeks and theater geeks and drunkard geeks and Greek geeks and math geeks and jock geeks etc etc etc. The nice part about that is that even though you can factor out the geek part and find people with your interests, everyone here has at least that in common. We're incredibly driven, passionate people, and that doesn't have to be about schoolwork or politics or saving the environment. There are people who are incredibly passionate about producing plays, or charting the climate conditions in Ecuador, or traveling book salesmen in Victorian America, or playing football, or playing Halo. 

I think the clincher is that we feel at home in this environment, with these people. I go to my hometown and find that I'm not nearly as comfortable as I am here. I like who I've become here. It really is a surreal, magical place, and I wouldn't trade it for the world.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review:
It's New Haven. Deal. It rains. A lot. It's kinda gray. But when it's nice out, it's gorgeous. And New Haven in the summer is just amazing. Too bad we're here for the crappy months. 

Luckily, though, because of the lake effect, it usually doesn't get crazy cold here. So that's one positive.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: good snow, good east coast weather, nothing outrageous.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Lots of Renovations and Essence of the Old – A lot of buildings are being built/will be built/are being renovated. Awesome library (bass), biggest college gym in the world, beautiful campus.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: It's Bipolar – The weather here can be absolutely BEAUTIFUL, especially during the early fall and the end of the spring semester. But there are also a lot of rainy days, and those can get pretty miserable. It also gets pretty darn cold.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Residential College System – The residential college system vs regular dorm housing is great.  It really helps to break the larger Yale community into smaller chunks of people that you will live near for all 4 years.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: I wish we had a student center but the residential college system doesn't make that an option. Facilities are really great-couldn't ask for better. Beautiful libraries, many gyms, etc.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: You Need Your Own Computer – Bring your own computer! It won't work otherwise-I don't know anyone that doesn't have their own computer. However the computer labs are really good and wireless access is excellent! Bringing a printer is recommended to avoid printing costs of 7 cents a page but not strictly necessary. Either way though don't print out online articles for your classes-you will waste a lot of money. Just read them on your computer.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: New Haven is not a particularly safe place. The driving is terrible and there is little to no interaction between students and New Haven residents-the divide between Yale areas of New Haven and other areas is startling. Most students I know stay within Yale and don't do much exploring of the area. I think people should do more exploring (though not at night) because there are a lot of interesting parks, restaurants, and community service organizations off campus.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review:
I love Yale. However, this is an intense place. It is a "work hard play hard" school. Teachers will not coddle you, and the college as a whole does not provide much emotional support. This is not a school where people will hold your hand. The keys to loving Yale for me have been fivefold in spite of this:

1) My friends. Friends can help make or break a college experience. Studying is all well and good, but at the end of the day, having wonderful people to be with makes any college experience great. I have loved the opportunity to meet and become close to people from all over the world; a lot of my friends are from very different backgrounds than me, but we have a lot in common. This is very refreshing.
2) The classes and educational opportunities. Yale has an astounding array of interesting classes. Shopping period, while sometimes horribly stressful, allows you to explore many classes. Take advantage of that. Yale also has many wonderful educational talks, Master's Teas, etc. If you love to learn, you can be learning new things every day, in interesting ways.
3) The financial aid. Yale gives EXCELLENT financial aid. Enough said.
4) The International Summer Award-Yale gives you money to go abroad one summer. Need I say more? I plan to go next summer.
5) The college experience in general-college is stimulating and challenging, and forces you to grow and become independent in dozens of unexpected ways, as cliche as it sounds. Yale is incredibly stimulating as well as being incredibly challenging, and as such it is an exciting place to spend your college years.

Finally, don't do all the reading. Learn to skim. It makes things much easier.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: No one comes to New Haven for the weather. I have lived in the New Haven area my whole life, and would like to move to a nicer climate upon graduation. New Haven is intermittently cold, but the cold is not the problem: the problem are the gray, cloudy skies, which show up with irritating regularity. Expect a lot of rain and many days that start off sunny and turn cloudy. There is also little to no horizon in New Haven. Also, when it snows, don't expect classes to be canceled. Weather gets better come mid-April and May, just when everyone is studying for finals.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: People here are so down-to-earth and friendly.  I think the wonderful, diverse, happy, fun-loving crowd of students here really sets Yale apart from *other* similar schools.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: New Haven definitely has a gray season.  It's a bit humid and rainy in the early fall, and cold in the winter.  As the Northeast goes, though, it's pretty average.  It's beautiful in the fall and summer!
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: It's New England – I'm from California.  It snows here and gets cold.  The worst is when the snow starts melting and then freezes into giant grey clumps along the sidewalk.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: Sometimes Wet and Cold – I'm from New England so it doesn't really bother me. But it rains a lot.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: The school computers are in general very slow. However, some of the libraries seem to be getting faster ones. Most students have their own so there are always free ones.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Cold in Winter, Humid in Summer – Just like any area in the northeastern US, New Haven experiences relatively wet weather, from humid heat during the summer to rain during the fall. Snow comes occasionally, and is not inhibitory to transportation, though it can be wet. The cold during the winter might be a shock to those from warmer areas, but is nothing out of the norm for those used to it.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: I'm Singing in the Rain – So New Haven is wetter than I expected, but being from Seattle, it feels more like home. The rains are tolerable if you have an umbrella, rain boots, and coat, anyways. There are also some shuttle buses you can take if you don't feel very Gene Kelly-esque on a particular day. But the weather's been pretty mild so far, and warmer than back home for me. I've heard that it gets cold, and that snow will come soon, but it's also supposed to melt quickly. And then spring is supposed to be gorgeous here. So just remember your rain gear, appreciate the cleansing feel of rainfall, and you'll be just fine.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Loud and Dull – New Haven is loud, dull, and town-gown relations are strained.  Students generally make their own fun on campus instead of heading into the city.  However, there is some nice shopping off campus, and food options are great.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Always Investing in Campus – Yale is in a constant state of renovation.  The university is basically the bread and butter of contractors in the area.  All of the residential colleges are scheduled to be renovated within two more years, and buildings, libraries, and classrooms often have custom wood paneling and pretty elaborate detail.  Most people don't take the time to realize the care put into facilities here, but everything is about as nice as a public space can be.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review:
Light Fellowship Rules – If you want to study an Asian language, come to Yale.  The Light Fellowship gives you a free ride to study over the summer, for a semester, or for a year at prestigious programs in Japan, China, and Korea.  

There are also other international opportunities, of course.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review:
Rain, So Bring an Umbrella – It rains all the time.  Bring an umbrella.  But, if you, like I, love the rain, the weather is lovely.  It is cool starting in September, and gets colder and colder.  Fortunately, the dorms and classrooms are very well-heated.

Fall is beautiful.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: I'll start with academics. Yale offers amazing classes in almost everything you could imagine, and it doesn't stop after the school year. The summer programs, whether you want to take classes abroad for credit, or work, or have an unpaid internship are numerous and very fufilling. Plus yale's financial aid packages are really unparalleled, they cover 100 percent of need based aid. The social scene is great, far better than i expected from an ivy league school. Wednesday through Saturday people go out. There is one club most people frequent but there are at least five or six others within ten minutes walking distance from the farthest of residential colleges and there are dozens and dozens of cool bars. Campus life is really fun. nobody's stuck up and everyone has something they're really into. it's a great place to go to school.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Sometimes It Rains. Big Deal. Sometimes it rains in new haven. I'm from sunny central florida and it really doesn't bother me that much. the fartherst i'd ever have to walk for class would be like ten minutes and even then if i really wanted to i guess i could catch a bus. There's a little snow but not that much. plus, it's pretty.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: The Facilities at yale are awesome. As a student athlete i'm grateful to have such amazing and well maintained athletic facilities. The nine story Payne Whitney Gymnasium is not only beautiful on the outside but it offers a state of the art work out facility and classes in every workout fad imaginable.  The libraries are wonderful with every book you would ever need and several million you won't. They are also beautiful spaces, visitors are often taken aback inside SML, our main library, which literally looks like a giant beautiful cathedral. There facilities for everything you could think of and it's all beautiful. We have the lock on gothic architecture obviously, but there's also a ton of georgian revival, and modern architecture as well. Every student dorm has it's own dining hall, library, computer labs, and basement with weightlifting rooms, a buttery, a huge multimedia center, ping pong, pool, some even have things like DDR or a basketball court!
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review:
Not for the Thin of Blood – New Haven is simply gorgeous in fall and spring: there are trees all over the place.  Students flood intocdourtyards and Old Campus on warmer days to hang out, play frisbee, and watch passing tour groups.

It rains fairly frequently in the spring and fall, but not unnecessarily so (keeps the lawns green).  Just bring your rain boots and umbrella.

Winter, however, is another story.  It's not horribly cold in the Have, which means that most of our winter precipitation comes in the form of rain or ice.  Ice also often collects on the gothic stone walkways and the wind can be bitter.  As a Southern girl, winter is really difficult (especially so my freshmen year) but you find ways of compensating, such as exploiting dining hall coffee and curling up with friends and hot cocoa inside.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Rain Rain, Go Away – Winters are sooooo long. It's raining right now, ew.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: If you're from the east coast, the random tropical (yes, tropical) thunder showers, temperature dips and heat spells, the cold, and gray skies will be nothing new to you. West coasters will discover the magic of snow and clothing that actually covers your body. Nothing spectacularly different here, just New England weather, no different from anywhere else in the region (except for being a little warmer than say, Boston). While people will always complain about rain "ruining plans", it's really not remotely a big deal and people will do whatever they want to and need to regardless. And snow is just a lot of fun - don't be surprised if you get pulled into a spontaneous snowball fight!
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: The One and Only – Yale really has so so so many opportunities to offer its students. Our enormous endowment doubtlessly has to do with that. We have every activity that you can imagine -- and if you can imagine something else, Yale will fund it. The greatest professors in the world, an unbelievably driven and deep student body, beautiful residences, and a REAL social scene, I swear!
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: It's Yale - a degree from this school means something. Consulting firms are particularly eager to hire from the school.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: I want to work in a lab and do cancer research
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Yale has many opportunities for on campus jobs and internships.
Value.Author: College Student

Value.Review: I mean it's Yale...it's exactly what you'd expect it to be.  Not much else to say here
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: The quality of the work of anyone who goes here is very good.
Value.Author: College Student

Value.Review: You'll definitely get a job if you attend this school.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Yale students that try hard should be able to get jobs and opportunities.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: You can't go wrong with a degree from Yale.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: Can't say too much here, but pretty confident in the career office services here to assist in job/internship prospects.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: You definitely have to take initiative, but there are amazing resources
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: Many companies love hiring graduates from Yale. They know students here are hard-working, dedicated, and intelligent. Recruitment and career services are great here.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: Yale's financial aid is one of the most generous in the nation, but the financial aid office employees are for the most part nasty and stingy with it. They are a huge pain to deal with but at the end of the day 200k in financial aid makes me happy.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: Not enough workers at financial aid office.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: Financial aid to cover tuition was incredible. However, making the student contribution was stressful and difficult, scholarship also didn't cover ancillary living expenses.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Financial aid is dependent on need, so I can't really offer any tips - but if the need is there, Yale delivers! Yale's staff has been incredibly helpful with making sure I have everything I need to apply for aid, and the process is very straight forward. I have to work on campus, but the hours are minimal and certainly manageable.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Compared to other places, Yale and its peer institutions are the best. There aren't any merit-based scholarships since it's elite enough that most people that go there would qualify anyway. Financial aid application can be a hassle, especially when you have a difficult or complicated family situation, but in the end it's worth it since students that really need financial aid usually get lots. Definitely call the financial aid office if you run into any problems, or go into the office if you're already on campus.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: It took me several attempts to get a financial aid package, which was supposed to be enough to allow me to pay for school without a loan. However, I still needed to take a loan in order to pay tuition.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Yale is need-blind and they meet 100% of need. After I got my regular decision schools' FA packages, I and my mom both called the office to say that Pomona gave me $5000 more in loan-free package, and Yale ended up matching and throwing in an extra $2000. Always call!
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: The people aren't very helpful and the information on the website is misleading.
Value.Author: College Student

Value.Review: Yale, with the size of its endowment, should have better financial aid policies. Even if families do not have to contribute, students have to pay up to $6,400 just from their student job. This contribution limits students' abilities to perform since they are so busy working, and despite Yale's promise that students will graduate debt-free, many students must take out loans to cover their contribution. In comparison to other Ivy Leagues, Yale could do better.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: This school cost me less than any other school I was accepted to. The Student Income Contribution sorta sucks, but the aid here is fantastic for low-income students.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Finding scholarships and grants is relatively easy, however the process is quite hard to apply. They do provide everything online but I feel like I have to navigate through a bunch of pages to find what I am looking for.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Yale is the best. It's not perfect, but everything is amazing.
Value.Author: Recent Alumnus

Value.Review: Look everywhere for scholarships and ask for help with financial aid
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: This degree will get you work in any area of your field.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: AMAZING aid offered to me, so I can't complain, but the office is a pain to deal with and they are not very transparent.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: I am paying what I am able to based on my family situation. There was no extra work necessary (other than the already complicated FAFSA and CSS processes). However, I have heard of some nightmare situations in which people who have savings sort of get screwed over.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: It was actually pretty hard to get the aid I needed but it all worked out eventually :)
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: The engineering department is relatively young/weak so there aren't as many connections for students as there are at other schools like Princeton, Harvard, or Stanford. If you're in the humanities though you're in good shape.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: Yale School of Music provides full scholarships and small stipends to all admitted students. On-Campus work pays well and is enjoyable and related to my field of study.
Value.Author: College Senior

Value.Review: It's an expensive school, so except a high cost. Yale really does do it's best to defray the costs though.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: Yale is need-blind and has very generous financial aid packages for all students who can't afford to pay for college.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: Yale scholarships made this kind of education cheaper than a state school for me.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: It's need based, but when they count your assets, they include things like your house, rather than just resources you can actually use to pay tuition. So it's very generous, but middle class families especially still end up with loans.
Value.Author: Recent Alumnus

Value.Review: Yale was my first choice school and they gave me the best financial aid package. It's need-based and no loans, and for my friends who didn't get the aid they thought they needed, they were able to work with the financial aid office to work something out. They also have an ISA that helps fund study abroad in the summer!
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: Yale provides need-based financial aid
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: School is expensive and as long as the federal government allows for schools to charge the max to students, they will continue to be drowned in student loans for the rest of their lives.  There is no accountability or sense of responsibility from school administrators of the impact of their budgets being paid out on the backs of their student body.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: I am basically not paying a dime to attend Yale. Their financial aid department is actually one of the best things that has ever happened to me. I'm more thankful for the financial aid at Yale than for anything else.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Financial aid process is great, but the financial aid that's actually given is pretty mediocre
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: Yale is incredible with its financial aid outreach
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: The financial aid here is better than the offers from Harvard, Princeton, Stanford, MIT, and Caltech.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: The financial aid process was somewhat confusing, and there were an immense amount of forms that seemed to all have the same questions.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: As an Ivy League institution, Yale doesn't offer merit scholarships to incoming students, but they are very good at assessing your family's specific needs and giving you the appropriate amount of financial aid. If you disagree, call the financial aid office and you may even get a little more money. And most of the time, no loans!
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: It was easy to apply and the office was good at answering questions.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: I ended up getting pretty much the level of aid I needed, but the process became much more complicated as the years progressed. I would assume it probably had to do with the increased amount of students that needed financial aid due to the recession, but it was frustrating nonetheless.
Value.Author: College Senior

Value.Review: I receive pretty good financial aid,  but the way they estimate expenses is sort of weird. They expect you to supplement it with a student job for "personal expenses", but sometimes it takes a wicked long time to find a job. Overall, I can't really complain too much. I am receiving a quality education for a super low price (comparatively).
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: I received financial aid on time, but there are many papers and applications to fill out to make sure you get what you need.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: The University helped me so much with financial aid -- their need-based scholarships are wonderful!
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: Truly Need Based – Yale is incredibly generous with financial aid. Most students get some, and the average financial aid package is well over half the cost of attendance. It is a very easy process, and the school will make sure you have the funding you need.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Yale is unparalleled at providing financial aid- if you get in, they make sure you have the option to come, plain and simple.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Cheaper Than State School If You Need It – Yale aid is need based and pledges to meet 100% of need. Furthermore, if you family makes less than 200K annually, they won't pay more than 10% of their income. Honestly, I've paid more for student contribution than my parents' contribution, which was easy considering that on-campus jobs pay over $10/hour as min wage.
Value.Author: College Senior

Value.Review: Yale gives really good financial aid. That's why I'm here.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: The financial aid I received is THE only reason I'm here.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: It's easy to do, and I got a good amount of financial aid.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: The food is great in options... But not if you're health conscious. There are soooo many options that are unhealthy, but very few healthy options, and even fewer healthy options that taste OK
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: New Haven has an incredible amount of restaurants, just venture a bit out of the Yale bubble to find them!
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: The campus food is almost entirely hit-or-miss unless you are in Morse or Stiles because you can always get delicious pizza from there.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: Delicious food, but not diverse enough sometimes.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: There are several bars frequented by students, not much my scene so I wouldn't know how they compare to those in major cities.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Quite a bit of it can be bland. I wouldn't say that any particular dish is exceptional but variety compensates at times.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Even though all of the colleges serve the same items at meal times, there is usually enough variety offered to find something that sounds more than appetizing
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: There are a lot of ethnic Asian food places, namely Japanese sushi places and Indian food places that have a lot of vegetarian options. New Haven had pretty interesting places to eat if you can afford it.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: The buffet-style is great since you can have as much of whatever you want. Freshman year you're forced to get the full meal plan. Expensive but convenient since you get three meals a day, and you can choose where on campus you want to eat so location-wise it's convenient too. The meal plan that has less meals a week is probably better since oftentimes you have food events with clubs/organizations or want to try a local restaurant (great places in New Haven) or don't wake up in time for breakfast.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: A lot of great spots to eat, only problem is there's not that many late night spots unless you down to walk a few blocks
Food.Author: College Student

Food.Review: they try too hard to offer vegan/tofu/gluten free food when only a small fraction of the student body eat it. Give us real food yale. Aint nobody tryna eat a vegan burger
Food.Author: College Student

Food.Review: Most people say the restaurants here are great. However, I don't really like eating out so I don't enjoy it as much as others.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: No student discounts, but New Haven has amazing food
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: can eat at any dining halls
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: New Haven is the foodie capital of the world. 'Nuff said.
Food.Author: College Student

Food.Review: Really good food compared to what you can find at other schools.
Food.Author: College Student

Food.Review: Depending on where you go, you have different experiences. My favorite is an Indian restaurant named Tikkiway.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: The food, like at any other university, has its good days and its bad days. There is always variety with some regular staples like a salad bar, a yogurt bar, a cereal bar, and Stiles always has pizza and ice cream readily available.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: There are some GREAT vegan/GF options nearby
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: 12 dining halls to choose from plus Commons, gluten-free options, pretty varied, vegetarian friendly, can use Lunch swipes at an overpriced snack store, Durfee's
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: It's great because there is a variety, and you can always get a salad or make a sandwich. There is vegan and gluten-free options as well. The system of using your lunch swipe for a Durfee's swipe is OK, but the food in Durfee's is way overpriced so you end up not getting the equivalent of a lunch swipe.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Eating options are great and varied off campus and not in dining buildings.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: For the most part, the food is wonderful. Probably some of the best college food you'll come across. However, some of the ethnic foods they make aren't quite good due to lack of seasoning/spice. The rice is just always bland, for example.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: There are so many good restaurants in New Haven, including two of the best pizza shops in the country. There are a lot of wonderful Thai and Indian places that I frequent and are basically on campus. I'm convinced no other college has access to this much good local food.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: New Haven is a major dining destination. It has some of the best pizza in the country (seriously, New Haven style pizza is a thing. Pizza afficionados rave about Sally's and Pepe's from across the country). People come from twenty to thirty minutes away to dine in the area surrounding Yale University, so it has some great choices in the slightly to completely out of a normal student's budget range. However, there are also a number of student friendly options, from the ever popular Yorkside for diner food and pizza, to York Street Noodle and Mamoon's for a more ethnic experience. Even Miya's, a high end sushi restaurant, has an amazing late night selection aimed at current Yale students.
Food.Author: Recent Alumnus

Food.Review: Many different and ethinically diverse options widely spread around the city.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: I now live in a much more expensive city, so I appreciate how cost-effective the options were.
